IV. Suggestions Concerning Format
1. To be effective, the series should probably have a minimum of 20 broad¬
casts; or it might be planned in two sections of, say, 10 to 15 each, with the
first section on an experimental basis and the second to be undertaken if the
initial experiment proves successful.
2. The programs should be not less than 30 minutes in length and preferably
45. Forty-five minutes or more allows much greater flexibility, room to experi¬
ment, and if the programs are well planned, the longer time makes possible a more
effective job in terms of information and education.
3. It might be desirable to plan a series in related groups of three or four
broadcasts leaving either the 4th or 5th period open for a topical subject which
could be arranged on shorter notice. For a program of this kind to have the maxi¬
mum educational value, it seems desirable to avoid the buckshot approach. In other
words, there should be some pattern of development. The area is sufficiently large
and has enough concrete problems to make for plenty of variety and interest. An
international discussion series should be topical in character, but if it had to
be planned on a week-to-week basis, it would be almost impossible to organize, and
the programs would suffer in quality. However, with advance planning, one can be
reasonably sure to selecting topical subjects and at the same time make allowance
for considering new and unexpected developments by leaving an occasional period
open.
4. There should be a general pattern of approach keeping in mind the practical
problems of organization, but no fixed format for each broadcast. The formats
should be varied to fit the topic and circumstances. For example, big names in
the international field are desirable for prestige and publicity purposes, as well
as for authoritative official views, but it is usually impossible to get a foreign
secretary or prime minister to take part in a discussion. However, it is much
easier to secure a recorded statement of four or five minutes which could be in¬
corporated in the program. Similarly, if you wanted a spokesman from some other
country, say the Prime Minister of Egypt on the Suez Canal, a statement might be
secured by beam and line or by recording. If some topic seems to demand a two- or
three-way discussion between the officials of different countries, the necessary
circuits could be secured to make it possible.
5. For ease of operation, I think that in general topics should be allocated
and points of origin assigned for each program so that the national organization
concerned would assume responsibility for arranging and producing the program in
consultation with the coordinator-director. This is probably a simpler and more
practical method than trying to handle everything from a central point or to
assemble individual programs, say, in New York or Chicago, by means of recordings,
although naturally there would need to be cooperation in securing recorded state¬
ments or live pick-ups from time to time as required.
